lessons.title: 1. The Role of Science in the Surrounding World

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Everything around us can be attributed to science, scientific processes, and phenomena. We can divide science into two categories: natural science and social science. Observe the world around you and take a picture of something you see that you can connect to a natural science phenomena. Add a caption to this image describing what you see, how it connects to this phenomena or process, and describe the phenomena or process as well.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Humans are constantly advancing, in the fields of science, technology, and so much more. In order to innovate and advance, some people have to be ‚Äúthe first.‚Äù For example, Abu Nasir Al-Farabi, was one of the first to study the stars. Understanding and knowledge of the stars gives us insights into how the whole world works. Think of a recent innovation, invention, or discovery. Do some research into who, or what group of people, led to this development. How did it happen? What would life be like without this development?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Do some research into an invention or development that provides a sustainable alternative, addresses an environmental issue, or something similar. Describe it in a few paragraphs here. Do you think the development you chose will be widely accepted? Why or why not? If not, what would you do to help its chances at success?

content.text: Understanding science and its role in everything in our lives is a great start to being able to contribute to its development! Our understanding of science leads to our understanding of the environment and how we can prevent harm to it. There are many new firsts in sustainability and developments that address climate change.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: What is something you can observe with your eyes that tells you that something else is occurring, that you can‚Äôt necessarily observe with your eyes? For example, I can tell that when there‚Äôs condensation on the outside of a glass of water, that the water inside is cooler than the outside air. What is an example of something like this in nature? Take a picture of this observation and add a caption describing what you are seeing.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: There are certain measurements taken about our climate that can tell us a lot about the environment and quality of life in that area. One of these measurements is the Air Quality Index. Look it up for where you live. What does it say? What does this tell you about the area? What changes would you expect to see if it went up? How about if it went down?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Next, identify sustainable alternatives and solutions on the market. How could you measure the success of these sustainable solutions? What metrics and measurements would you need to know these things are helping our environment?

content.text: There‚Äôs many experimental procedures and methods for testing and measuring things in nature. It is important to have methods for measuring sustainability, the health of our environment, and the amount of harmful substances in our environment and atmosphere. Identify activities or substances that are harmful for our environment. How are these things measured? What are the metrics for these things? If you‚Äôre unsure, do some research and write a paragraph about what you find.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a walk outside, looking for parts of nature that could be part of an experiment. Find 3 inspirations, take pictures of them, and caption each with what you would test in an experiment. Make sure that these things are testable and that you could realistically test these things yourself.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Pick one of the experiment ideas you came up with in the previous activity. Design an experiment that could be conducted over one week. Identify a testable hypothesis, the dependent and independent variables, and the procedure of the experiment to start. Next conduct the experiment. After, you should include your results in a table, and create a graph or diagram that shows the results of the experiment. Write a concluding paragraph about the results of the experiment, what you tested, and finally, why it is important to analyze results.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Choose two different areas of the world and compare the metrics of climate change in both these areas. What do these results show you? Analyze the results.

content.text: There are metrics and ways to evaluate climate change. What are some examples that can show climate change? How would you evaluate these metrics?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Going outside on a clear and cloudless night, take a photo of the starry sky with your smartphone or Camera üì∑. Add a title and date to your photo. Try to find constellations familiar to you in the photograph and write down their names.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How would you describe light years to a student younger than you?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Show the correct sequence of starry sky objects in descending order (from largest to smallest).

content.text: The Universe
Milky Way
Solar System
Stars

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Questions: How does the experiment you conducted relate to light, constellations, and light pollution? Conclude the impact of light pollution on the environment.

content.text: You already know that some of the sources of environmental pollution are cars, thermal power plants, and industrial enterprises. But other sources lead to light pollution that can make stargazing difficult.

Light pollution is the illumination of the night by artificial light sources (electric lamps, fire, etc.), interfering with astronomical observations and changing the biorhythms of living organisms. It represents excessive use of outdoor light and has many harmful effects on the environment.
To better understand the process of light pollution, let's conduct a small experiment.

Conditions and materials for the experiment: The room where the experiment will be carried out should have curtains on the windows to darken the room so that no artificial light comes in and it is possible to control the amount of light received and the light source (flashlight). A flashlight, a sheet of thick paper of a dark (black) color, scissors, a pencil, a pin or paper clip for fixation, and adhesive tape (duct tape, tape).
Using scissors, cut a piece of dark paper into a circle so that it is larger than the front of your flashlight.
Using pencils or a pen, make several holes in the piece of paper. The holes should resemble your zodiac sign constellations (Aries, Sagittarius, Capricorn, etc.) or as you wish.
Tightly attach the paper ready for the experiment to the front of the flashlight with adhesive tape (duct tape, tape) so that there is no gap at the edges.
Take the flashlight to a darkened room.
Turn on the flashlight and aim the light at the ceiling. If you don't see anything on the ceiling, you will need to enlarge the holes on the paper.
Then point the flashlight back at the ceiling and use curtains or blinds to add some light to the room. Observe how your constellations are visible.
Repeat the experiment, but subject to increased lighting of the room.
Record your observations in the table.
Try to leave comments on your observations in this experiment.

lessons.title: 2. The Sun and the Solar System

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: The light emitted by the Sun falls on the Earth. Some of the sunlight is reflected by the Earth's surface, while the other part is absorbed. Take a walk around your school or in your yard and take a few photographs of surfaces that absorb sunlight (soil, grass, hard surfaces). Then take a photo of surfaces that reflect light (snow, ice, mirrors, white surfaces, polished metals). Compare the pictures with each other and draw appropriate conclusions.

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Arrange the planets of the solar system from those farthest to those closest to Earth.

content.text: Neptune
Uranus
Saturn
Jupiter
Mars
Earth
Venus
Mercury

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the correct match for the composition of substances of celestial bodies

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: How can you implement your ideas to reduce light pollution? How possible is it to implement your proposals? What do you need to solve this problem and what kind of help do you need?

content.text: In the last lesson, you used an experiment to visualize a model of light pollution. Now you need to do a little research. Using materials from online resources, you need to find information about the consequences of light pollution on the environment.
Answer the following questions:
What do you mean by light pollution?
Name the sources of light pollution.
List some examples of the effects of light pollution on the environment.
Offer recommendations to reduce the impact of light pollution on the environment.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take several photos of the same landscape in the morning, afternoon and evening. Compare the pictures with each other based on lighting conditions. Find the connection between lighting conditions and the position of the Earth relative to the Sun.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is associated with the change of seasons (spring, summer, autumn, winter) of the year on Earth?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Example/Hint: I noticed that my family and I take plastic water bottles to school or work. I know that it would be more sustainable to use a reusable water bottle that I can fill instead of using plastic. This would contribute to less waste that is harmful to the environment. My plan to implement this is to collect data to present to my family about the harms of plastic waste. I then will show them options for reusable water bottles, and water filters to make sure we are drinking clean water. I would also add up the numbers to show them that using reusable water bottles will save my family money!

content.text: At this point in your life, you probably have at least a basic understanding of what everyday actions are helpful or harmful to our earth. Pick a couple of hours at home to observe the actions of yourself and your family at some point in the day. Think critically about the consequences of everyday actions.

After you‚Äôre done observing, identify an action or habit done by yourself or your family as a whole, that you think has a negative impact on the environment. Come up with a way to address this action or habit that could improve it or replace it. Additionally, identify how this change would be better for the environment.
Create a plan to implement this change and try it out for at least a week. How difficult do you think this will be?

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a photograph of a small area of nature. Explain its role in your life and human society as a whole.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is a geochronological table? What information does it contain?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Put the following stages of Earth‚Äôs development in order, starting with the earliest:

content.text: Archean era
Proterozoic era
Paleozoic era
Mesozoic era
Cenozoic era

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: What are some things or actions that drive up the production of these gasses? Do some research to answer this question. Once you identify some of these things, brainstorm some actions that could decrease greenhouse gas emissions. Finally, identify organizations that are already doing work to improve greenhouse gas levels in our atmosphere.

content.text: Knowledge of the main gasses and their role is important to understanding how our planet came to be. While some gasses play an important role in life for our planet, others can pose a danger to the Earth. There are seven gasses called greenhouse gasses, which, when released into the atmosphere in large quantities, cause serious harm to the environment, leading to climate warming.
Carbon dioxide
Methane
Nitrous oxide
Hydrofluorocarbons
Perfluorocarbons
Sulfur hexafluoride
Nitrogen trifluoride

lessons.title: 5. The Structure of the Earth and its Shells

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Draw on a piece of paper the process of an earthquake. Upload your drawing here.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is plate tectonics? What causes the movement of lithospheric plates? What consequences can they cause?

content.title: common:reorder
content.prompt: Arrange the layers of the earth's crust as you move into the interior of the Earth:

content.text: Crust
Mantle
Outer core
Inner core

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Create a presentation that explains solar energy, how it works, and the benefits of it to the homeowner and to the environment. Your presentation should be convincing and geared towards an audience of homeowners who you would like to get involved in solar energy.

content.text: The resources and materials that are important to our lives and the creation of common objects, come from the earth. Some of these materials come from underground. Some materials are also non-renewable. Therefore, there is a finite amount of these resources.

Some non-renewable resources are coal, natural gas, and oil. Many of these nonrenewable resources and the methods used to get them, can be really harmful to the earth. There are alternative options to these resources. These alternatives include the use of wind or solar energy. The use of solar panels is an increasingly popular alternative that many homeowners are opting for.

lessons.title: 6. The Origin of Life on Earth

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture of any living organism. Think about a part of their structure that is important to their survival. Then add a caption about why you think that part is necessary for life.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Organisms evolve and adapt to their environment, causing them to change over time. If our climate continues to warm, what development will be important for species to make? Come up with a couple ideas.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Read the linked article about the situation in Kazakhstan. What would you suggest Kazakhstan do to better protect endangered species?

content.text: Life on earth has its limitations, and all species have not been successful on it. There are many species that have gone extinct, or at risk of extinction. As humans, it is important that we make sustainable decisions in order to keep the habitats of these animals intact.

lessons.title: 1. From the Map to the Plan of the Local Land

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Pick a place that you visit so often, you don‚Äôt need directions to get there. Use your house as the starting point and draw the directions to get there by memory. Approximate where the turns are and the distance of each turn. For example, if you walk on Main Street for around twice as long as Corner Road, the line showing Main Street should be double the length of Corner Road when you draw it. Upload a picture of your drawing.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Chingiz is looking at a map with a scale of 1cm to 1km. He measures that the distance between two points on the map is 5.75cm. How far away is the actual distance between these two points in real life?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is azimuth? How do you find it?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Wildfires can destroy forests and the wildlife in them. Do some research to answer the following questions: What causes wildfires? What could humans do to decrease wildfires? Have there been any wildfires near you?

content.text: The land, climate, and environmental conditions in an area can change over time due to natural influences, and heavily by human actions. Forests are very important pieces of our world and bigger environment, but a lot of things threaten them.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a walk around your neighborhood and identify something that would need a symbol on a map. Take a picture of it, and then indicate what symbol it would need.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Why are symbols on a map important? How are they helpful for everyone?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the following symbols to their meaning.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Put together an elevator pitch for why people should consider these alternatives over clear cutting. You‚Äôll need to do research on the consequences and alternatives to do this well.

content.text: Last lesson, you researched wildfires and their impacts on forests. Another way that forests are harmed, through direct human intervention, is clear-cutting of forests. Clear-cutting is when large expanses of trees are cut down at one time, leading to a loss of biodiversity, increase of erosion, contamination of water, and many other issues.
There are alternatives to clear-cutting that are better for forests such as, selective logging or patch cutting.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: What is a landmark in your area that lets you know you‚Äôre close to home? Take a picture of it. Is this landmark natural or man-made?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is surveying? How do you do it?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: Why is it important for people to be able to read a map? How do you think technology has affected that skill?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Choose a human impact or natural disaster that you think would lead to habitat loss for a certain species. Brainstorm a plan for how you would help this species and/or prevent this act from occuring in the future. Thoroughly explain your idea, what you would need, possible challenges, etc. Be creative!

content.text: Changes in the topography of certain areas and changes in conditions don‚Äôt just affect what we see on a map. Wildfires, clear-cutting, and other serious acts can lead to large habitat loss for many species. Habitat loss leads to death of species and risk of endangerment.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Brainstorm a hands on way that you can mimic the idea of Pangea and its separation. Take a picture of your representation. For example: Pieces of a jigsaw fitting together and then being moved apart.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How would you describe Pangea to a student younger than you?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Take a couple pictures of your experience.

content.text: Keeping the land of our world clean is incredibly important for our health and the health of all wildlife. Pick an area of your community that you can clean up. With a group of friends or with your family, spend 1 hour cleaning up trash in this area. You‚Äôre helping the health of this area, but also preserving its beauty!

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Find nearby water in your area. This can be anywhere between a small stream, up to a large lake‚Ä¶ anything! Take a picture of what you find. Does this water appear polluted?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How have the methods for measuring ocean depth changed throughout time?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What difficulties do glaciers pose for sailing? How do glaciers affect water levels and our freshwater supply?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Pick one of these, or an idea of your own, and conduct some more research. With this research, create an infographic educating others on what they can do to help our oceans. Include evidence, visuals, and a convincing pitch. Work with your parents to share this to social media or with family members!

content.text: Plastic is harmful to our environment for many reasons. It takes a very long time to break down, and it also presents many threats to marine life. Plastic can harm them due to threats of consumption, entanglement, and habitat destruction. There are a bunch of things that we can do as individuals to help.
Cut the plastic rings that come with the packaging of bulk beverages to prevent animal entanglement
When shopping, bring a reusable bag instead of using plastic bags
Use a reusable water bottle instead of plastic
Recycle plastic
Opt for products that come from recycled materials

lessons.title: 6. Distribution of People on the Surface of the Earth

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: Take a picture of a highly populated area near you. Take note of the conditions in this area and provide a couple comments on your thoughts.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What did the people of Kazakhstan do during ancient times?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: How and why did people end up spread out across the world?

content.title: common:sorting
content.prompt: Match the ancient civilization to the river that they settled by.

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Is this number bigger or smaller than the United Nations‚Äô average? What could you do in your household to decrease your amount of waste?

content.text: With the amount of people throughout the world, it is important to ensure we are practicing responsible consumption. The United Nations estimates that the average person wastes 120kgs of food every year. Being conscious every day of what we are consuming, and how much we are wasting is a way to make sure we are being responsible.
Throughout this week, conduct an experiment with your family to analyze how much food you are wasting.
You‚Äôll need: a bucket and a scale

Before you add anything to the bucket, weigh it to find your starting weight that you‚Äôll deduct later. You‚Äôre tasked with tracking the amount of food left on the plates of everyone in your family after dinner for a week. Do this by adding anything left on the plates to the bucket. At the end of the week, weigh it. Subtract the weight of the bucket without anything in it to find the total weight of food wasted.

There are 52 weeks in a year. Multiply the weight you got by 52 to find your estimated amount of food wasted per year in your household. Then, divide this number by the number of people in your household to find the average amount of food wasted per person.

content.title: common:snapshot
content.prompt: There are many different races and ethnicities within Kazakhstan. Draw a self-portrait and explain what you find most important about your culture. Upload this picture.

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is one aspect of a culture different from yours that you find interesting? Why do you find it interesting? How did you first learn about this culture?

content.title: common:imageboom
content.prompt: What is an ethnic group (ethnos)?

content.title: common:mastery
content.prompt: Brainstorm things that lower income households could implement for sustainable change that would not be costly to them. Choose one of these ideas and write out how you would pitch this idea to these households. If it will help your pitch, do some research on price differences/savings.

content.text: Around the world, there are many inequalities within society that can unfairly affect certain groups. There are inequalities in regard to race, social class, sexuality, and more.
When it comes to developing sustainable habits, some changes can be more expensive, keeping people with lower income from being able to join in on sustainability.
